definition: to confuse one thing with another (idiom); to muddle
confused/dirty/to mix/muddy/variant of 渾|浑[hun2]
to mix/to mingle/muddled/to drift along/to muddle along/to pass for/to get along with sb/thoughtless/reckless
variant of 為|为[wei4], because of/for/to
because of/for/to
variant of 為|为[wei2]/as (i.e. in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do
as (in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do/by (in the passive voice)
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
to speak/to talk/to converse/to chat/to discuss
surname Tan

sentences.english: The issues of race and class are separate and should not be conflated.
sentences.chinese: 种族与阶级问题各不相关，不能混为一谈。
别将事实与虚构混为一谈。

sentences.english: I don't mix work and dating.
sentences.chinese: 我不想把工作和约会混为一谈。

sentences.english: Don’t confound public affairs with private ones.
sentences.chinese: 不要把公事与私事混为一谈。

sentences.english: In fact, they appear to be confusing ability with precocity .
sentences.chinese: 事实上，他们将早熟与能力混为一谈。

sentences.english: He did not like a mixture of frivolity with the serious business of the hunt.
sentences.chinese: 他不喜欢把嬉戏和打猎这件严肃认真的事情混为一谈。
不要把自由与放纵混为一谈。

sentences.english: We should not confuse lack of implementation with lack of evidence.
sentences.chinese: 我们不应当把实施不力与缺少依据混为一谈。

sentences.english: Some people often confuse the text and tables, a little note here.
sentences.chinese: 有人常将桌和案混为一谈，这里稍加说明。

sentences.english: But this is just another product of the conflation of money and capital.
sentences.chinese: 但这是又一个将货币与资本混为一谈而得出的结论。

sentences.english: And I still have mixed feelings. I mean, how can you conflate cigarettes and tampons ?
sentences.chinese: 我的意思是，你怎么能把香烟及卫生棉条混为一谈？

sentences.english: Some even confused the detection method of oil-water separator material with this detection method.
sentences.chinese: 甚至有人将油水分离材料的检测方法与此混为一谈。

sentences.english: The conflation of money and capital is one of the crippling weaknesses of mainstream economic thought.
sentences.chinese: 把货币和资本混为一谈是主流经济学思想的七寸。

sentences.english: People equdined on success in life with the proficiency of operating computer .
sentences.chinese: 人们把会利用计算机与人生乐成混为一谈。

sentences.english: Don't mix the two things togther and keep them apart.
sentences.chinese: 别把两件事混为一谈，应该把它们分开。

sentences.english: This should not be confused with measurements of shoot elongation.
sentences.chinese: 该情况不应与枝梢延伸测定混为一谈。

definition: to equate/to consider (two things) to be equivalent
to obscure/to confuse/to mix up/to blur/to mislead
to confuse/to muddle/to mix up
two quite different things/two unrelated matters
two quite different things/another kettle of fish
to mix up/to confuse one thing with another
completely/sharply (differing)
to equate/equal to
to distinguish (between different things)/to make distinctions clear
to regard as
(math.) equals sign =
to lump different matters together (idiom)
to take sth for granted
see 沒關係|没关系[mei2 guan1 xi5]
to misunderstand/to misread/misunderstanding
to discuss two disparate things together (idiom); to mention on equal terms/to place on a par with/(often with negatives: impossible to mention X in the same breath as Y)
